speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.3: Technology Plan - The board will review a proposal to expand digital learning access by providing Chromebooks to every high school student. This initiative is estimated to cost $10,000 annually for devices, maintenance, and licensing. The program is designed to ensure equitable access to technology, support blended learning, and prepare students with digital skills for college and career readiness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I am excited about this topic. As we move towards 21st-century teaching methods and more online resources become available, it only makes sense that our kids have equal access to them. The question remains how will it be possible within our budget but if done right I see this as a game-changer. If each high school student has a device that they can access at home, what exactly do we plan to roll out in terms of infrastructure to ensure that internet connectivity and Wi-Fi are accessible across both homes and schools?   Do we expect that parents will have to take some burden in having reliable broadband internet service to facilitate this effort as well? How will these devices protect against cyberbullying? How will privacy laws interact with these electronic tools?  Are we creating new staff positions to support teachers using these devices effectively in their classrooms? What about professional development plans so educators are familiarized with integrating them into the curriculum, particularly in subjects such as math and foreign languages where tech skills have been proven to create significant growth in performance? With all that being said, I'm really proud to consider investing in these opportunities which provide better access for historically under-resourced populations while also acknowledging potential obstacles which should give everyone pause as we're weighing whether they are surmountable. We will do this carefully but decisively with an emphasis on equity. But again. I think the biggest challenge is going to be providing these computers for those who cannot afford internet access after they get home from school. It is one thing to issue the devices, but if there's not connectivity back there for whatever reason, it may further exacerbate those gaps instead of narrowing them. So in conclusion, I think this could be a powerful tool that gives us momentum and equality, and it was important enough to make sure the public was fully aware of this investment decision. And even more important than getting input on any plan will require follow up in progress, monitoring in real time on how things work out once implemented and also the ongoing need to re-evaluate resource allocation based upon evolving results. Thank you.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
Thank you for your thoughtful questions. To address Mr. Alcaro's first question on broadband access at home and infrastructure, we understand its importance. Our administration is currently discussing partnerships with local internet providers, considering the possible provision of low-cost options for families who struggle to secure reliable internet services. That work, however, has yet to conclude, because, quite frankly, it involves complex policy discussions. I think as we explore these digital equity challenges, the district, as part of the comprehensive technology plan rollout, will continue to seek the community's guidance on addressing home connectivity via several stakeholder engagement sessions that will allow parents, guardians, the education workforce, and other relevant groups share ideas and help our organization refine how best to tackle the broadband and Wi-Fi accessibility hurdles at home.
```

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you, Ms. Callsen. A lot of the times we focus on trying to fix systemic issues within our own silo, which is a lot of the reason why there might be limited impact in long run because once children leave our walls, there are still factors that prevent them from accessing critical tools required for continued success. That collaboration sounds promising to me. How do you envision working with the board as partners in refining policy through engaging key stakeholders while keeping us informed over the course of this process, recognizing our budgeting process has already placed constraints on how quickly they respond to identified needs?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I couldn't agree more.  For instance, a partnership with the city library system could also allow them access, during certain hours, to secure internet connectivity. In terms of ensuring transparency throughout this policy refinement, we propose regularly scheduled check-ins with the Board for quarterly updates on the digital equity taskforce stakeholder feedback and our response to emerging concerns. While yes, we recognize the existing financial pressures imposed by our budgetary timeline, we believe staying closely connected with the Board empowers responsive adaptations should shifts occur to accommodate this technology rollout's broader community implications.  It becomes essential that we monitor our initial pilot outcomes before adjusting next year's budget.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank you, Katrinas for outlining the steps you're proposing to ensure equitable internet access beyond school grounds. I'd like to emphasize the significance of these collaborative efforts, not just with local internet providers but also with community organizations, to bridge the gap between our students' varying circumstances. By doing so, we can guarantee that no student is left behind due to lack of connectivity. As we move forward, I suggest we prioritize establishing clear goals and benchmarks to measure our progress toward digital equity, allowing us to adapt our strategies accordingly. Mr. Alcaro, your concerns about monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of this initiative resonated strongly with me; we must hold ourselves accountable for the investments we're making and their impact on our students' lives.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I appreciate Director Oberg's points. I want to clarify that those check-ins that Ms. Callsen mentioned should indeed involve benchmarks to help assess their effectiveness. Without metrics tied to specific desired outcomes, the efficacy of our approach would remain unclear, rendering us ineffective stewards. Therefore, as we discuss, our commitment to evidence-informed decision-making remains crucial. I wholeheartedly concur that we keep students with unique barriers first and foremost within our line of sight, understanding the potential long-term impacts of our actions today.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Directors Oberg and Alcaro, thank you both for reinforcing the need for metrics-based assessments, specifically tying to outcomes related to increased student academic achievement and bridging the divide in access to technology. Indeed, identifying these critical checkpoints upfront will enable our district to pivot strategically when needed and allocate resources most efficiently in pursuit of the educational equity we seek. As such, our team agrees that quarterly evaluation of benchmarks becomes integral to gauging program effectiveness and driving strategic adaptation.

speaker: judyle
content: I'd like to build upon this discussion by highlighting the critical role teacher training plays in successful device integration and blended learning models. To ensure equitable access to technology translates into meaningful instructional experiences, we must invest in professional development opportunities that empower educators to effectively incorporate digital tools into their pedagogy. This, in turn, enables teachers to support diverse learners and foster deeper understanding among students. Can we consider allocating additional funding towards teacher training initiatives focused on digital literacy, culturally responsive teaching practices, and data-driven instruction?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Teacher preparation is absolutely vital to the effective integration of these devices and ensuring that the technology supports inclusive, culturally responsive instruction.  In fact, our staff has discussed this very point extensively - that we cannot simply drop technology into classrooms without providing our educators with the necessary training and support to utilize it in ways that promote student-centered, equity-focused learning environments.  I wholeheartedly endorse Judy's proposal that we dedicate additional resources towards educator professional development in these areas.  This commitment will ultimately enhance the overall impact of our one-to-one device initiative.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I completely agree with Directors Cuff and Le, emphasizing the importance of investing in teacher training and professional development. As we strive for equity and excellence in our digital learning environment, it's crucial that our educators feel confident and prepared to harness technology in ways that promote inclusive, student-centered instruction. I recommend we explore leveraging district and external resources to provide ongoing support for teachers, including coaching, mentorship, and peer-to-peer learning opportunities, to ensure they stay updated on best practices in digital literacy, culturally responsive teaching, and data-driven instruction.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: What I hear in all three of your requests, Ms. Le, Ms. Cuff, and Dr. Osborne, is the emphasis on an equitable approach that focuses on improving students' learning experiences.  The device rollout itself is certainly a significant step, but it's only a tool unless our educators possess the skills required to effectively integrate its use across different teaching methods.  To amplify this, it seems pivotal that we develop well-designed teacher training initiatives, which not only promote educators' technical competence but equally highlight culturally responsive teaching strategies. We should explore flexible solutions involving both internal and external partnerships to offer sustained coaching, mentoring, and peer-to-peer knowledge sharing opportunities. Only then may we hope to achieve impactful change in this domain. It is imperative now that we also begin to lay out clear expectations around what professional development for our teachers will look like within the context of this project and ensure our budget planning mirrors our commitment to this work and its follow-through.  Kate?  What thoughts do you have on structuring such professional development components going forward?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Indeed, we need to design and deliver comprehensive professional development programming that aligns with our stated goals and priorities around cultural responsiveness and equity. Our district already possesses expertise from past experience, which we can leverage while supplementing these strengths through strategic external partnerships. I envision crafting multi-faceted support structures encompassing workshops, peer coaching circles, and ongoing job-embedded coaching, thereby equipping educators to employ technology in ways promoting culturally sustaining practice and informed instructional decisions. Furthermore, we could establish an internal 'Teacher Leader Network', consisting of educators well-versed in culturally responsive digital learning strategies who can support colleagues during implementation phases.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Directors Le, Cuff, Osborne, and Alcaro, for underscoring the imperative of thoughtful teacher training and professional development tailored to advance equity-centered digital learning. The multifaceted structure envisioned by Director Cuff – featuring workshops, coaching, and embedded support – echoes my sentiments. Moreover, the idea of an internal Teacher Leader Network will likely prove invaluable in scaling our capacity and fostering peer-to-peer collaboration among educators as well as creating consistency throughout our educational ecosystem. I propose incorporating these recommendations into our planning framework moving ahead, with a focus on culturally responsive digital pedagogies and data-driven decision-making essential to maximizing the benefits derived from our one-to-one device initiative. We should also examine how to sustainably fund these crucial support elements over time. Could we request updates on potential partnership collaborations and resource identification efforts, considering this new professional development plan alongside its corresponding budgetary requirements at our next meeting?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I appreciate the collective emphasis on equity-centered teacher professional development, supporting our educators in meaningfully integrating technology into their instructional practices. To ensure a cohesive strategy, let's task our administration to present a detailed proposal outlining the structure, timeline, and budgetary implications of the recommended multi-faceted professional development program. This would allow us to assess alignment with our core objectives, evaluate potential partnerships, and review long-term sustainability considerations for these crucial investments in our educators.

speaker: judyle
content: I concur with Director Berg's suggestion, and I believe it's essential to include specific metrics and benchmarks for evaluating the effectiveness of our professional development programs. By doing so, we can track progress, identify areas for improvement, and make data-driven decisions to refine our approach. Additionally, I propose that we schedule regular check-ins with our Teacher Leader Network to gather feedback, address emerging concerns, and celebrate successes, thus ensuring our professional development initiatives remain adaptive, responsive, and centered on the needs of our educators and students.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I thoroughly agree with Directors Callisen, Berg, and Le. A detailed proposal with budget implications and evaluation metrics is exactly what we require to move this initiative forward. These components are fundamental to assessing our success and adapting our approach. In addition to benchmarking, I suggest we build in a mechanism for continuous improvement, using our educators' voices to inform refinements to the professional development program. This might entail setting up quarterly town hall-style meetings with the Teacher Leader Network, plus other representative educator groups, to garner insights and input. By doing so, we'll not only improve the quality and relevance of our PD offerings but also further cultivate a culture of collaboration and collective ownership within our education community.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I wholeheartedly endorse the call for a comprehensive proposal outlining the structure, timeline, and budgetary implications of our multi-faceted professional development program. I also strongly support the inclusion of evaluation metrics and benchmarks to gauge the effectiveness of our efforts. Director Cuff's suggestion to incorporate quarterly town hall-style meetings with the Teacher Leader Network and other educator groups will help ensure that our professional development initiatives remain grounded in the needs and perspectives of our educators and students. Furthermore, I recommend that we consider embedding a research component into our evaluation framework, examining the impact of our one-to-one device initiative on student outcomes, particularly for historically under-resourced student populations. By taking a data-driven and evidence-based approach, we can refine our strategy, optimize resource allocation, and ultimately drive meaningful improvements in teaching and learning.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: As all directors appear to be united behind requesting a detailed proposal that outlines a comprehensive professional development program, complete with a budget, timeline, and metrics, we've reached some consensus tonight.  I concur with this path, as any attempt at large-scale implementation without rigorous planning and analysis would undoubtedly result in suboptimal outcomes.  Furthermore, these checks and balances will help to ensure accountability and guarantee fiscal responsibility when investing in such key components.  If the Superintendent accepts the scope of this directive, an administrative presentation during our following meeting focused on a detailed plan should provide valuable insight.  One final thought - In the pursuit of data-informed instruction, our professional development must equip teachers to engage students in data analysis as well, arming them with data literacy skills and the capacity to act upon the findings.  Our kids should increasingly take agency in tracking their own academic progress.  And so, it seems wise to make sure our professional development explicitly addresses student roles inside the digital classroom while building data-literacy competencies. It remains crucial that our vision prioritizes culturally responsive approaches and is attentive to historical disparities, making certain every stakeholder is aligned with our objectives.  I invite Dr. Osborne to respond to this notion if she wishes.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I couldn't agree more, Director Alcaro. Empowering students to take an active role in tracking their own academic progress through data analysis is a critical aspect of cultivating agency and ownership in their learning journey. Moreover, equipping them with data literacy skills will prepare them for success in an increasingly data-driven world. I wholeheartedly support the integration of student-centered data analysis into our professional development program, with a keen focus on culturally responsive approaches that acknowledge and address historical disparities. This will not only enhance our students' ability to navigate digital tools but also foster a deeper understanding of their own strengths, challenges, and areas for growth. By doing so, we can promote a more inclusive and equitable learning environment where every student has the opportunity to thrive.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks, Dr. Osborne, for your strong leadership and guidance throughout this discussion. The way you frame this concept resonates deeply with me - fostering agency in our students by having them co-pilot their academic progress with data analysis, especially given our goals around digital pedagogy and culturally responsive practice. This could have profoundly positive impacts on closing persistent opportunity gaps. I now formally motion that we direct the administration to present at the next meeting a fully formed proposal encompassing the facets described here: professional development structure, timeline, cost estimates, clear metrics for assessment, and consideration of our students' vital role in data interpretation. Second?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you everyone for voting. After counting all the votes, we have 6 (public) / 5 (private) in favor, 1 (public) / 1 (private) against, and 0 (public) / 1 (private) abstaining. Results → Public: approved, Private: approved, Combined: approved. Thank you everyone for coming, have a nice night.
